articles.title: Grandparents raising grandkids get a lifeline in New Mexico’s free child care expansion
articles.summary: BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM When New Mexico rolled out its landmark universal child care program, most headlines focused on working parents. But tucked into the policy is a quieter, deeply meaningful change: grandparents who are raising their grandchildren can now access free child care, even if they are retired or no longer in […]
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

When New Mexico rolled out its landmark universal child care program, most headlines focused on working parents. But tucked into the policy is a quieter, deeply meaningful change: grandparents who are raising their grandchildren can now access free child care, even if they are retired or no longer in the workforce.

For thousands of families across the state, this shift is more than a regulatory tweak. It is a recognition of reality.

New Mexico has the highest rate of grandparents and other relatives caring for children in the nation. Between 2021 and 2023, about eight percent of children in the state were living in kinship care, more than double the national average of three percent. Many of these grandparents stepped in during moments of crisis, often with little warning and limited financial support.

Why grandparents were previously shut out

In most states, child care subsidies are tied to work or school requirements. Caregivers must prove they are employed or enrolled in education to qualify. That framework left many grandparents out.

As state officials gathered input from families over the past two years, the same story surfaced again and again. Grandparents who had taken on parenting roles later in life did not qualify for assistance because they were retired. Many were living on fixed incomes, facing the physical demands of caring for young children, and struggling to cover child care costs that can exceed $13,000 a year.

New Mexico’s substance abuse crisis has intensified this need. According to the Los Alamos National Laboratory Foundation, about 16 percent of the state’s adult, non-senior population struggles with substance abuse. In 2021, New Mexico ranked first in alcohol-related deaths and sixth in drug overdose deaths nationwide. These realities have pushed many grandparents into caregiving roles unexpectedly.

At the same time, roughly one in three grandparents raising grandchildren in the state lives at or below the poverty line.

A policy designed to reflect real families

Under the new universal child care rules, grandparents with legal custody or kinship guardianship are explicitly exempt from work and school requirements. That change makes them newly eligible for free care.

“We wanted grandparents to see that we see them and that we recognize they are doing hero’s work by taking care of their grandchildren,” said Elizabeth Groginsky, New Mexico’s cabinet secretary for early childhood education.

Other states offer limited exemptions for kinship caregivers. Grace Reef, president of the Early Learning Policy Group, notes that 21 states have some version of this policy. But those exemptions are often buried in complex regulations. New Mexico’s approach stands out for its simplicity and scale.

“New Mexico’s approach is simpler and more universally applicable to grandparents, helping reduce confusion and barriers for grandparents seeking child care access for their family,” said Anne Hedgepeth, senior vice president of policy and research at Child Care Aware of America.

Early signs of impact

Before the universal program launched, about 916 children in grandparent-led households received child care assistance in fiscal year 2025. In just the first three weeks of the new system, 61 additional grandparent-headed households were approved for care.

For advocates and providers, the change is long overdue. Barbara Tedrow, who owns five child care centers in Farmington, said she often felt compelled to waive tuition for grandparents who suddenly found themselves caring for toddlers they could not afford to enroll.

“They were older, and they weren’t working. They were in their 70s taking care of a two-year-old,” Tedrow said. “There was no way they could afford the tuition. So we as providers were normally just letting them come for free.”

Tedrow added that consistent care is especially important for children who have already experienced trauma. “Let this child at least stay during their core hours getting fed, getting nurtured, educated, playing with other children their age,” she said. “‘I’m 70. I don’t know where to go find two-year-olds for my granddaughter to play with.’”

What grandparents say they really need

Jovanna Archuleta, early childhood program director at the LANL Foundation, said grandparents consistently emphasize flexibility. Many do not need full-day care every day. What they need is relief.

“They need respite care,” Archuleta said. “They need drop-in spots and times where they can just have time for themselves.”

One grandparent quoted in the LANL report described days packed with school drop-offs, meals, laundry, homework, and bedtime routines. “By the way I am 70 and a disabled vet, and a widow,” she wrote.

Caring for young children is demanding at any age. For older adults, it can be even more physically and emotionally exhausting.

The biggest challenge ahead: capacity

Policy alone does not create child care slots. New Mexico now faces the challenge of building enough capacity to meet demand.

Even before universal care, about 80 percent of children were eligible for assistance, yet only around 35 percent of eligible children under age five actually received it. Long waitlists, limited provider participation, and a shrinking number of home-based providers have all contributed to gaps.

From 2010 to 2025, New Mexico saw registered home-based providers drop from 4,840 to just 821. To meet demand, the state estimates it needs 55 new child care centers and 1,120 additional home-based providers.

To get there, New Mexico is offering low-interest loans from a $13 million fund to expand or build centers, raising reimbursement rates, and streamlining payments to providers. It has also reduced some barriers for home-based providers, though challenges remain.

“The majority of those families live with extended family or roommates,” said Lucy Leon, a former home-based provider. “From the jump it’s like, ‘There’s no way I’m going to do a background check for my husband, my son, and much less a coworker.’ That’s another great barrier.”

A model with national implications

New Mexico’s universal child care program is funded through years of preparation, including oil and gas tax revenues and a voter-approved constitutional amendment championed by Latinas in the state. The early childhood fund has grown from $320 million in 2020 to $10 billion today.

As states like New York and Georgia explore similar proposals, advocates are watching closely. Nationwide, the number of grandparents raising grandchildren has been rising for 25 years, driven in part by the opioid epidemic.

“If we are going to invest a huge amount of money into a universal child care system, let’s hold an ambitious goal for what it delivers to families,” said Natalie Renew, executive director of Home Grown. “I don’t think it’s going to be easy, but I think it is possible.”

For New Mexico’s grandparents, the message is already clear. The state has acknowledged their role, their sacrifice, and their need for support. And for families built on love rather than paperwork, that recognition matters.

articles.title: Press release - Parliament to fast-track support loan for Ukraine
articles.summary: Following the decision to apply its so-called “urgency procedure”, MEPs will vote on a proposal for a €90 billion support loan to Ukraine at an upcoming plenary session.Committee on BudgetsCommittee on International TradeCommittee on Security and Defence Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Tuesday Parliament backed, by a show of hands, a request to fast-track its legislative processes on an EU financial package to support Ukraine. The proposal would introduce a €90 billion EU support loan for Ukraine, financed through common EU borrowing from capital markets and guaranteed by the so-called “headroom” of the EU budget. This new instrument, if adopted, would provide military assistance and general budget support to the government in Kyiv, as well as support Ukraine’s defence industry and its integration into the European Defence Industrial Base.

In parallel, MEPs also decided to fast-track their work on an accompanying proposal to amend the so-called Ukraine Facility and on the decision by the Council to apply the enhanced cooperation procedure to enable 24 member states (excluding Czechia, Hungary and Slovakia) to provide Ukraine with the above-mentioned loan. The latter proposal will be put to a final vote by MEPs on Wednesday, 21 January.

Next steps

With the European Parliament having kicked off its work, the loan will now have to be agreed between MEPs and Council under the ordinary legislative procedure.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Parliament fast-tracking a substantial €90 billion support loan for Ukraine, which will provide military and budget assistance, supporting Ukraine's defense and integration into the European Defence Industrial Base. This has broad significance for European security, humanitarian support, and geopolitical stability, benefiting a large population and promoting peace and resilience.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament speeds up €90 billion loan to support Ukraine
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) is working to support Ukraine during a difficult time by providing financial help. Usually, big decisions like this take a long time to approve.

**What happened** – On Tuesday, the European Parliament decided to speed up the process to approve a €90 billion loan for Ukraine. This loan will be paid back later and is funded by the EU borrowing money together. The loan will help Ukraine’s government with money for daily needs, military support, and strengthening its defense industry to work closely with Europe.

**Impact** – This loan is one of the biggest financial support packages ever proposed by the EU. It will help Ukraine defend itself and keep its government running. It also helps Ukraine’s defense companies join with European ones, which can make Ukraine stronger in the future.

**What's next step** – The European Parliament will soon vote on a related plan to allow 24 EU countries to provide this loan, excluding Czechia, Hungary, and Slovakia. After that, the Parliament and the EU Council will work together to finalize the loan agreement.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament is fast-tracking a major €90 billion loan to help Ukraine with military and budget support, aiming to strengthen its defense and ties with Europe.

articles.title: Press release - EU competitiveness: MEPs propose new legal framework for innovative companies
articles.summary: A single set of pan European harmonised rules should deepen the single market and boost cross-border investment.Committee on Legal Affairs Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
With 492 votes in favour, 144 against and 28 abstentions, MEPs adopted a series of recommendations on Tuesday that will feed into the Commission proposal for a new legal framework supporting companies in the EU that is expected in the coming months. Under this anticipated new framework, EU countries would be able to either create a new corporate form or incorporate EU-wide rules into an existing one. MEPs insist on a single harmonised set of rules known as the “28th regime” to ensure a level playing field for businesses across the EU.

Fast digital registration

This Unified European Company (S.EU) would apply to non-listed limited liability companies based in one of the 27 EU countries. Registration of an S.EU should be fully digital and able to be completed in 48 hours, requiring a minimum paid-in capital of only one euro. To promote the seamless operation of S.EUs within the internal market, including digital communication with authorities and digital information for investors, MEPs want a Commission-operated uniform digital multilingual portal accessible across all EU member states.

Attracting investment and talent

MEPs want to ease access for S.EUs to investment, including via alternative financing models, while ensuring optional protection schemes, such as the separation of voting and economic rights or profit distribution based on contractual agreements limited in time or amount. They also propose rules to attract and retain top talent in S.EUs including via employee stock-ownership plans and employee stock options.

Transfer of knowledge and specialised dispute-resolution

Parliament says S.EUs should be able to commercialise fundamental research and calls for measures that would ensure improved cooperation between SMEs, start-ups, scale-ups and research institutions in the EU. S.EUs should have access to specialised and accelerated dispute resolution mechanism that could be conducted in English.

Quote

Following the vote, rapporteur René Repasi (S&D, DE) said: “Today's vote shows that Europe can and must fix what has long held innovators back against global competitors. Our vision of the S.EU would allow companies to set up within 48 hours, fully digitally and across borders. At the same time, the European Parliament wants to see robust social standards as part of this new regime."

Background

Parliament’s priorities regarding the so-called 28th regime for EU companies are intended to feed into a legislative proposal by the Commission, expected by MEPs in the first quarter of 2026 and which should be backed by robust funding.

Press conference

The rapporteur will brief journalists following the plenary vote, on Tuesday 20 January 2026 at 15.00 CET in Strasbourg.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant legislative initiative by the European Parliament to create a harmonized legal framework for innovative companies across the EU, which will simplify cross-border business operations, promote investment, and support innovation. This has broad positive societal and economic impact by fostering entrepreneurship, attracting talent, and enhancing cooperation between research institutions and businesses. The story focuses on a single, well-detailed topic with clear benefits for the general public and the EU economy.
articles.personality_title: EU lawmakers back new digital company rules to boost innovation and investment
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) is working to make it easier for businesses to operate across its 27 member countries. Currently, different rules in each country can make it hard for companies to expand or attract investors.

**What happened** – On January 20, 2026, the European Parliament voted to support a plan for a new legal framework called the "28th regime." This plan will create a single set of rules for a new type of company called the Unified European Company (S.EU). These companies would be able to register fully online within 48 hours, with just one euro of starting capital needed. The plan also includes a digital portal to help companies communicate with authorities and investors across all EU countries.

**Impact** – This new framework will make it simpler and faster for small and medium-sized companies to grow across borders. It encourages investment by allowing flexible financial arrangements and offers ways to keep talented employees through stock options. The plan also supports better cooperation between businesses and research institutions, helping companies turn new ideas into real products. A special system for solving disputes quickly in English will make business smoother.

**What's next step** – The European Commission will use the Parliament’s recommendations to create a formal law proposal expected in early 2026. If approved, the new rules could be adopted and start helping companies soon after. The Parliament will continue to monitor the process and promote strong social protections alongside business benefits.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is creating a fast, digital, and unified legal system to help innovative companies grow, invest, and work easily across Europe.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les députés européens approuvent de nouvelles règles numériques pour stimuler l'innovation et l'investissement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne (UE) cherche à faciliter les activités des entreprises dans ses 27 pays membres. Aujourd'hui, des règles différentes dans chaque pays compliquent l'expansion des entreprises et l'attraction d'investisseurs.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 20 janvier 2026, le Parlement européen a soutenu un plan pour un nouveau cadre juridique appelé « 28e régime ». Ce plan créera un ensemble unique de règles pour un nouveau type d'entreprise, la Société Européenne Unifiée (S.EU). Ces entreprises pourront s'enregistrer totalement en ligne en 48 heures, avec seulement un euro de capital de départ. Le plan comprend aussi un portail numérique pour faciliter la communication avec les autorités et les investisseurs dans tous les pays de l'UE.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau cadre simplifiera et accélérera la croissance des petites et moyennes entreprises à travers les frontières. Il encourage l'investissement grâce à des arrangements financiers flexibles et aide à retenir les talents via des options d'achat d'actions. Le plan soutient aussi une meilleure coopération entre entreprises et institutions de recherche, aidant à transformer les idées en produits. Un système spécial de résolution rapide des conflits en anglais facilitera les affaires.

**Prochaine étape** – La Commission européenne utilisera ces recommandations pour créer une proposition de loi officielle attendue début 2026. Si elle est adoptée, les nouvelles règles pourront rapidement aider les entreprises. Le Parlement continuera à suivre le processus et à promouvoir des protections sociales solides.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE crée un système juridique rapide, numérique et unifié pour aider les entreprises innovantes à grandir, investir et travailler facilement dans toute l’Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: Los legisladores de la UE apoyan nuevas reglas digitales para impulsar la innovación y la inversión
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) busca facilitar que las empresas operen en sus 27 países miembros. Actualmente, diferentes reglas en cada país dificultan que las empresas crezcan o atraigan inversores.

**Qué pasó** – El 20 de enero de 2026, el Parlamento Europeo apoyó un plan para un nuevo marco legal llamado "28º régimen". Este plan creará un conjunto único de reglas para un nuevo tipo de empresa llamada Compañía Europea Unificada (S.EU). Estas empresas podrán registrarse totalmente en línea en 48 horas, con solo un euro de capital inicial. El plan también incluye un portal digital para ayudar a las empresas a comunicarse con autoridades e inversores en todos los países de la UE.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo marco hará que sea más fácil y rápido para las pequeñas y medianas empresas crecer entre fronteras. Fomenta la inversión permitiendo acuerdos financieros flexibles y ofrece formas de retener talento mediante opciones sobre acciones. El plan también apoya una mejor cooperación entre empresas e instituciones de investigación, ayudando a convertir ideas en productos reales. Un sistema especial para resolver disputas rápidamente en inglés hará que los negocios sean más fluidos.

**Próximo paso** – La Comisión Europea usará las recomendaciones del Parlamento para crear una propuesta de ley formal que se espera a principios de 2026. Si se aprueba, las nuevas reglas podrían adoptarse y comenzar a ayudar a las empresas pronto. El Parlamento seguirá supervisando el proceso y promoviendo protecciones sociales fuertes.

**Resumen en una frase** – La UE está creando un sistema legal rápido, digital y unificado para ayudar a las empresas innovadoras a crecer, invertir y trabajar fácilmente en toda Europa.
